title: Why are the most popular spells unlocked at levels 8-10?
body:
Flash, Ignite, and Smite are currently unlocked to new players when their accounts reach levels 8 - 10.

Flash is used by over 95% of players, and Smite allows players to jungle. Why are they kept from new players for so long?

replies.body: That's a deliberate choice to help new players ease into the game. The jungle's extremely punishing if you don't know what you're doing, especially if you don't have many runes, so we don't want to encourage people into it with Smite immediately. Flash and Ignite by contrast are both a bit harder to use than Ghost and Heal in particular, hence they unlock later too. Some minor side benefit in that it also makes low level games a bit less lethal on average too (new players don't assess threat well, so die a lot already, helps a tiny bit to not exacerbate that).

While I agree about smite and jungling being hard without proper runes/masteries, the part about ignite and flash is total bs. Flash is a universal must-have spell at this point and ignite is a simple point and click dot spell. Should their cooldowns be wasted smart? Yeah. But they are not harder to use. On top of it all, it also creates some pretty infuriating power level difference together with a keystone mastery on early levels. Since matchmaking doesn't care whether or not you got flash and ignite or keystone, early levels are an even worse hell then dynamic queue.

I wouldn't say flash is a MUST have.. A lot of champions do better with Ghost than Flash. But, I see you point either way.. :]

"a lot" is an overstatement. I mean there's {{champion:2}} {{champion:106}} {{champion:120}} {{champion:19}} and that's it. Others are usually better off with flashing over the wall to get away or to chase.

As far as smite goes, that's more a byproduct of the jungle being so damn unforgiving. Can you imagine a level 3 jungler? There would be more executions than a Darius pentakill.

There's got to be a middle ground between "Everyone can jungle and stay there forever" and "Oh god I forgot my jungle runes, now I might die to blue".

Flash and Ignite by contrast are both a bit harder to use than Ghost and Heal in particular, hence they unlock later too. Some minor side benefit in that it also makes low level games a bit less lethal on average too (new players don't assess threat well, so die a lot already, helps a tiny bit to not exacerbate that).

I honestly think by making them unlocked later you're just making it hell for the newer players. Flash, ignite, and smite are the core of the game for the most part, not letting them get those because they're "hard to use" just means they're going to have to re-experience the game learning process at level 8-10, and also be told that most of the spells they had at low levels were actually not useful for them.

All of that is well and good, but isn't it a problem that you balance a necessary role (the PvE aspect of it) on players having access to an optional customization system with high levels of variance? 

Every other role can CS without fear of dying with a blank rune page.

If you prefer, we could always go back to, Season 4, was it?, where everyone could jungle pretty much forever without having to go back.

In any case, I think the fact that jungling takes some durability is a good thing. It helps encourage teams to bring a tank, particuarly when we're in a top-lane meta that might be more squisy.

https://i.imgur.com/1HvNiEO.png?noredirect

Except it doesn't, because you still have Nidalee, Graves, Kindred and the like jungling.

I do like the idea of the jungler being able to stay in the jungle forever. It's pretty difficult to gain and maintain map control when you have to worry about your health and mana levels from the environment, not because you screwed up a gank.

I could understand that but its not uncommon for new players to be matched against higher level accounts that have these summoners unlocked, which puts them at a disadvantage. Also, I would disagree that flash is harder to use because its an easy panic button to get out of a situation.

Smite in particular is very deliberately locked behind a level barrier; jungling is difficult enough that new players are not expected to cope with it. New players do not have runes or the knowledge needed to jungle sustainably, let alone effectively, and there's plenty of other things for them to be learning. So Smite is locked away to avoid drowning new players in even more strategy and gameplay mechanics.

Flash adds so much to the game that it sorta falls under the same category.

Ignite, not so much. Point, click, damage, done. Not sure why that one is locked away.

There's more then one way to do a tutorial.
Most of the time, though, we either force it or disguise it as the starting level. (See: Super Mario Bros. level 1 - 1)
